Description: Bead of square section: the bead is in opaque light-green glass with cylindrical, vertical piercing. Moulded with slightly rounded edges. Impressed on central area of each face is an undulating serpent in opaque white, black, yellow, and red. At the upper and lower edges of each face is impressed a prefabricated cord in opaque yellow and pale red. The cords were left in raised relief.
Curator's comments: For decades these beads have been described as 'cane glass beads' but the writer has been unable to find any justification for this term and knows of no literature on beads of this type. The wide vertical opening suggests a use on camel trappings and it is possible that they are of about the same vintage as the chevron beads. As the serpent motif is usually present on these beads it seems probable that it had the amuletic value of dispelling attacks by these reptiles. Cf. .6281 and 1939,0322.45.
